Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Immersive Brain Painting for College Students with ADHD

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: Each year many students diagnosed with Attention Deficit and Hyperactivity Disorders (ADHD) enroll in universities to pursue a degree; overall, it is estimated that up to 8% of college students with known disabilities are diagnosed with ADHD, while there are of course many more who are not formally diagnosed and for whom ADHD is a hidden disability. As a concrete example, the awardee institution currently has approximately 1,500 students with known disabilities of whom 342 are ADHD. Typically, these students are expected to perform at the same level as those with a high attention span; curricula and lectures are not designed with ADHD students in mind. So, while ADHD students may spend more time studying outside the classroom to compensate, they often fail to notice their attention has drifted until precious time has been wasted. Currently, there is no immersive neurophysiological tool to help improve attention retention and reduce mind wandering. The objective of this research is to explore to what extent ADHD students' attention retention can be improved through creating paintings with a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI). If successful, project outcomes will have broad impact by paving the way to a better and more successful life for students with poor attention spans, whether or not diagnosed with ADHD.<br/><br/>The research will establish a comprehensive and empirical method of investigating the effects of painting with the brain using a P300 stimulus to improve attention retention. Subjects will need to focus on a stimulus on a computer screen to create their desired image, which will require a lot of concentration to complete the task accurately and in a short amount of time. This skill once acquired could transfer to other situations requiring prolonged attention, thereby helping the students perform more successfully in school.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objective of this research was to assess the effectiveness of improving attention retention in college students diagnosed with ADHD and those with poor attention spans (without diagnosis) by employing abstract painting techniques with a non-invasive EEG-based Brain-Computer Interface (BCI). In this study, student volunteers interacted with Brain Painting by focusing on a stimulus presented on a computer screen to create a desired artwork. The stimulus consisted of objects (square, circle, triangle), colors (red, green, blue), and directional buttons. The BCI method integrated into Brain Painting was the well-established P300 speller method. This technique harnesses the P300 signal in the parietal lobe, which typically peaks at 300 milliseconds after a stimulus is presented to the user, in this case, the P300 speller method. Successfully executing this method demands considerable concentration to complete tasks accurately within a limited time frame.

We conducted a longitudinal study to evaluate the extent to which the Brain Painting application could enhance college students' attention. Each participant interacted with the system six times a week, for a total of three consecutive weeks. At the conclusion of this three-week period, participants reported perceiving improvements in their ability to sustain attention for extended durations through daily brain painting exercises. Nonetheless, several factors, including fatigue resulting from prolonged training sessions, discomfort from wearing the EEG device, and occasional drowsiness during the study, were identified as impediments to maintaining focus. Notably, there was a significant increase in attention retention from the first to the last session from both the EEG and self-reported attention scores.

In summary, Brain Painting exhibits the potential to assist college students in enhancing their attention retention. This research suggests that the application of the P300-based BCI in the context of brain painting can be beneficial for students diagnosed with ADHD and those experiencing attention challenges.
